Award.AwardTitle: Scientific Software Innovation Institute (S212) Workshop for Biological Collections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this national, interdisciplinary S2I2 workshop is to resolve and document the type of software architecture, platforms, and services needed to transform U.S. biological collection institutions into a highly network-integrated, virtual community of biodiversity data providers. The workshop will bring together professionals from the fields of research collection curation, software engineering, operations research, and production logistics. It will discuss the expectations of biological research collections community for national coordination of software innovation. It will also enumerate the properties and services such a center would need to incentivize and engage the community, including technical services, data entry workflows, software platforms and applications for efficient, scalable, computerization of un-digitized specimen collections. With its interdisciplinary expertise, the workshop will explore software options for moving from local-scale data capture and curation methodologies to innovative, national-scale tools for high-throughput computerization and annotation of biological specimen information.

The workshop?s findings will be synthesized into an electronic report on the meeting web site. It will inform NSF, scientists, and informatics researchers of the software and software support needed to create a national software architecture, platforms, and services, which would transform hundreds of U.S. zoological museums and herbaria into a vibrant virtual community of interacting biodiversity data providers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The biological collections held by the Nation’s museums, universities, government agencies, and research institutions represent a huge potential resource for research on the diversity of life, changes in the environment, agriculture, public health and safety, and even national security. But our ability to access these collections is limited by the very small fraction of the collections data that are available on-line. Of the estimated one billion biological specimens held in U.S. institutions, more than 90% have not been digitized – i.e. had their data transcribed into electronic form.

Capturing these data is an enormous challenge, especially given the current state of the economy and the limited public funds available. Advances in software engineering may hold the key to the process of collections digitization both faster and more efficient. Some of these may be entirely new, while others could be adapted from technologies already in use in the commercial world. It is also possible that software developed to deal with museum collections could be applied to problems in manufacturing.

With this in mind, we used funding from NSF to bring together a mixture of museum professionals, library and information scientists, software and robotics engineers, and management specialists to identify the requirements for rapid capture of data from museum specimens and how these needs might be met from future NSF programs.

Hosted by Chicago’s Field Museum of Natural History, this two day meeting took place in March of 2011 and was attended by 25 participants. Presentations on new perspectives in digitization, workflows, software, and community coordination were interspersed with break-out groups to consider the three questions in the light of these presentations and the experiences of the participants. Workshop participants also made a visit to the Automate 2011 tradeshow to look at some of the latest industrial-scale innovations in digitization hardware and software.

One of the most important findings to emerge from the workshop was the importance of understanding and documenting workflows in museums. In industry, for example, the process by which products are manufactured is carefully described in detail before work begins. This enables managers to use people and machinery in the most efficient way and to identify bottlenecks – places where serious delays can occur.

Overcoming bottlenecks is something that new software and other technologies might be able to do in museum collections, but before this can be done, the workflows in museums need to be described, so that we can identify what the main problems are and what solutions could be applied. To do this, museum staff need to be trained in the techniques of industrial engineering. So, using the remaining funds on the grant, we convened a second meeting, entitled Developing Robust Object Image Digitization (DROID), which was held at the University of Florida in Gainesville in June of 2012.

The University of Florida (along with Florida State University) hosts a national hub for collections digitization, called iDigBio, also funded by NSF.  We worked with staff from iDigBio to develop a meeting program that would focus on the challenges of workflow development in different types of collections that are commonly found in museums. There were 29 invited participants, who covered a broad range of collections types (specimens stored in fluid; dry specimens; pinned insects; flat sheets etc), all of who had prior experience of digitization. During the course of the meeting, participants were trained in standardized techniques for workflow description drawn from management science.
